Tom & all,
I haven't seen the koshirae for years, but based on Keith's desc=
ription and what I remember, this guard is mounted on the pole (not the nak=
ago) and would have served as a hand stop rather than a blade stop.  The ir=
on parrying bars would have taken care of other blades.  I don't recall any=
thing about the leather plate that would suggest that it wasn't contemporar=
y with the rest of the mounting, but my memory of it isn't good enough to b=
ase an argument on.  There is a somewhat similar koshirae at the bottom of =
page 82 of Bottomley and Hopson's "Arms and Armor of the Samurai."  Scanned=
 here for your convenience:
http://tinyurl.com/dd82

I suppose it's possibl=
e that someone transplanted a shinai tsuba onto the nagamaki koshirae.  But=
 on the other hand if you set out to make a round leather guard to go on a =
round wooden stick, I'm not sure how one for a nagamaki pole would or shoul=
d look different from one for a shinai.  Any ideas?

If we were talking abo=
ut a loose guard not associated with a koshirae, I'd agree with Mo that it'=
s much more likely to have been from a shinai or bokken than a nagamaki.  B=
ut this one did come on a nagamaki and we have other examples of pole arms =
mounted like this with a hand guard on the pole and parrying bars either mo=
unted on the nakago or on the pole.  Am I missing something?
Jim
